awd_titl_txt: Control-Theoretic Defense Strategies for Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will design next-generation defense mechanisms to protect critical infrastructures, such as power grids, large industrial plants, and water distribution systems. These critical infrastructures are complex primarily due to the integration of cyber and physical components, the presence of high-order behaviors and functions, and an intricate and large interconnection pattern. Malicious attackers can exploit the complexity of the infrastructure, and compromise a system's functionality through cyber attacks (that is hacking into the computation and communication systems) and/or physical attacks (tampering with the actuators, sensors and the control system). This work will develop mathematical models of critical infrastructures and attacks, develop intelligent control-theoretic security mechanisms, and validate the findings on an industry-accredited simulation platform. This project will directly impact national security and economic competitiveness, and the results will be available and useful to utility companies. To accompany the scientific advances, the investigators will also engage in educational efforts to bring this research to the classroom at UCR, and will disseminate their results via scientific publications. The work will also create several opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to engage in research at UCR, one of the nation's most ethnically diverse research-intensive institutions.

This study encompasses theoretical, computational, and experimental research at UCR aimed at characterizing vulnerabilities of complex cyber-physical systems, with a focus on electric power networks, and control-theoretic defense mechanisms to ensure protection and graceful performance degradation against accidental faults and malicious attacks. This project proposes a transformative approach to cyber-physical security, which builds on a unified control-theoretic framework to model cyber-physical systems, attacks, and defense strategies. This project will undertake three main research initiatives ranging from fundamental scientific and engineering research to analysis using industry-accepted simulation tools: (1) modeling and analysis of cyber-physical attacks, and their impact on system stability and performance; (2) design of monitors to reveal and distinguish between accidental and malignant contingencies; and (3) synthesis of adaptive defense strategies for stochastic and highly dynamic cyber-physical systems. Results will first be characterized from a pure control-theoretic perspective with focus on stochastic, switching, and dynamic cyber-physical systems, so as to highlight fundamental research challenges, and then specialized for the case of smart grid, so as to clarify the implementation of monitors, attacks, and defense strategies. The findings and strategies will be validated for the case of power networks by using the RTDS simulation system, which is an industry-accredited tool for real-time tests of dynamic behavior, faults, attacks, monitoring systems, and defensive strategies.

por.por_cntn:
The last years have witnessed a heavily increased number of attacks against cyber-physical systems, including the smart power grid, autonomous and interconnected cars, as well as general networked systems. Such attacks are not only sophisticated, but also fundamentally different from well-studied cyber worms and viruses, primarily because the main objectives of cyber-physical attacks are to deteriorate the performance of the control system, compromise safety, and perhaps take control pf the physical plant, rather than simply stealing protected information. Further, the properties of the physical plant make even more challenging to fully secure a cyber-physical system, because defense schemes need to comply with the laws of physics that regulate the physical plant (for instance, cyber-physical systems cannot be suddenly stopped after an attack, as it is usually done for purely cyber systems). Novel theories and tools are needed to secure cyber-physical systems, a critical need that motivated this research project. 

This research project has leveraged expertise in control systems, power systems, and infrastructure management to establish a new, unified and rigorous framework to design and protect general cyber-physical systems, and networked power systems in particular, from various attacks and failures. The analysis has revealed critical design and operational vulnerabilities, described coordinated attack techniques, and proposed adaptive monitoring and defense mechanisms. Results have been derived first from a pure control-theoretic perspective, and then specialized to the case of smart grid, so as to clarify the implementation of monitors, attacks, and remedial actions. In particular, the contributions of this project are aligned with three main directions. First, we have derived the first results to characterize detectability of attacks in stochastic control systems, where attacker has the additional possibility to hide the effect of the attacks within the nominal noise levels. These results have to be regarded as fundamental, and help the system operator to design more secure systems, enhance the security of legacy systems by placing additional strategic sensors, and quantify bounds on the severity of undetectable attacks. Second, we have characterized the performance of different detection schemes as a function of the detector’s knowledge of the system dynamics, including centralized, decentralized, and distributed, and we have shown that, because of the presence of noise in the system dynamics and because the attack strategy is essentially unknown, detectors with less knowledge of the system dynamics can, counterintuitively, outperform centralized detectors. This line of work has also revealed a fundamental tradeoff between privacy and security in interconnected systems, where, again counterintuitively, it is sometimes better to hide parts of the system (thus increasing privacy) in order to also increase security against unknown attacks. Third and finally, we have closely analyzed the dynamics of power systems, and we have characterized targeted attacks and defense strategies for this important cyber-physical system. We have identified the mechanism of “Dynamic Load Altering Attack”, where an attacker compromises loads implementing a demand-response protocol to initiate oscillations of the grid base frequency, and we have quantified the severity of such attacks as a function of the amount of compromised load. Additionally, we have designed efficient detection strategies to detect and identify such attacks, which exploit the frequency information contained in the response of the grid to the attack.

Because of the interdisciplinary nature of our study, this project has created several opportunities to bring together experts from control theory, power systems, and cyber security. We have organized invited and tutorial sessions in occasion of several international meetings, where we have promoted a dialogue between the communities, and have started the development of theoretically rigorous methods to address problems arising in cyber-physical security. We believe that it is a successful contribution of this project that several tracks at major controls conferences are now addressing problems in cyber-physical security. 

This project made significant theoretical and practical contributions to model, understand, and protect cyber-physical systems against a variety of attacks. While our results constitute a milestone in these directions, the need for more advanced and holistic security frameworks for cyber-physical systems is increasingly pressing. In our opinion, existing results rely on a set of simplifying assumptions on the dynamics of the physical plant, while real cyber-physical systems exhibit more and more complex dynamics. The extension of existing security tools to systems with complex dynamics is a promising and important research direction, which we are actively pursuing.
